posts.cooked: What are some good resources for learning about making a vendor library, like pathplannerlib? I’d like to learn about the differences between the jni/java/driver parts and the different utils you can use.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
We have a template, but not really much documentation to go along with it.

Contribute to wpilibsuite/vendor-template development by creating an account on GitHub.

They have access to pretty much all of wpilib, but certain layers have less access for compatibility reasons.

And for dummies like me, do you have any relevant resources for learning about the concepts needed for making a driver or JNI and HAL stuff? I have only ever been on the Java side of WPILib and I’d be happy to understand how the things under the engine work. I’ve heard many times people say “just JNI it” but I have no idea how that actually works.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
JNI is essentially just exposing native C/C++ code to the java app.  So it’s a matter of writing C++ code to do whatever you need (i.e. interact with lower level hardware), then exposing it through a JNI class

Of course, I glossed over a few things there, but you can look through the WPILib code to see examples of C++ and Java/JNI working together.

Edit: heres an example using the WPILib Accelerometer class.  You can use this as a starting point and look at other things based on the include/import lines at the top.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Search the Internet something like this how to make a JNI for java C++ and pick one to code the simple Hello World example. Some I notice first from a search that likely cover your needs (and more?): https://www.oracle.com/webfolder/technetwork/tutorials/obe/java/jni_obe/jni_obe.html https://www3.ntu.edu.sg/home/ehchua/programming/java/javanativeinterface.html

Understand JNI and the ability to bridge Java Bytecode with native C++.

link_counts.title: Implementing the Java Native Interface to Harden Native Code
Java Native Interface (JNI) - Java Programming Tutorial

posts.cooked: I get this error when trying to build the vendordep: g++.exe: fatal error: cannot specify '-o' with '-c', '-S' or '-E' with multiple files compilation terminated.
What’s a good way to publish the driver/cpp/java bundle? @mjansen4857 how did you do it for PathPlanner?
@Thad_House This error happens when I’m compiling on windows. When compiling on Linux everything is fine. How can I resolve this error?

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
It looks like it’s using a version of GCC you have installed and not msvc which it should be using on Windows. Do you have Visual Studio 2022 installed?
